Award.AwardTitle: CRI: CRD: VIDEO TRACES II - Designing, Creating, and Disseminating Video Traces for Networking Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
A number of new developments in video coding and networking are dramatically changing multimedia networking, including: (i) HDTV resolution video transmission over IP networks, (ii) fundamentally new scalable coding paradigms introduced with the scalability extensions of the H.264/AVC (Advanced Video Coding) codec, (iii) novel error resilience techniques, and (iv) the UMA (Universal Media Access) paradigm, which allows for unprecedented flexibility in content characterization and adaptivity in video transport. These new coding techniques open a vast research and development space for novel video transport mechanisms and make possible groundbreaking advances over existing mechanisms. To enable the exploration of this research space we (a) design trace characterizations of the new video coding paradigms, (b) create and disseminate an extensive publicly available library of video traces for these new codec developments, (c) conduct statistical analyses of the video traffic and quality and the video content features captured in the traces and (d) formulate usage guidelines for the trace library.

The intellectual merit of this community resource development project is the design of trace characterizations capturing the traffic, quality, and content features of video up to HDTV resolution coded with the new scalability, error-resilience, and UMA paradigms in video traces. The provision of both these traces and of the statistical analysis of the traffic, quality, and content characteristics will inform and advance networking, systems and video research.

The broader impact is provision of these sophisticated traces and analytical results in free and publicly available form. In particular, this video trace library allows the networking research community to keep pace with the developments in the video coding area and provides traces that reflect the properties of the video codings that will dominate the future Internet and wireless networks. The video trace library and the accompanying trace usage guidelines/tutorials enable and educate networking researchers without deep video coding expertise and/or without up-to-date equipment to conduct timely, high-quality research on a wide range of critical multimedia networking projects and hence to expand the research base.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivated by new developments in video coding that have led to vastly improved coding efficiency and flexibility compared to the previously widely considered MPEG-4 video coding, this computing research infrastructure project designed, created, and disseminated video traces of the H.264 Advanced Video Coding (AVC), H.264 Scalable Video Coding (SVC), and H.265 High Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) video codecs. The trace creation covered video formats up to the full high-definition (HD) format. In addition, video traces for three-dimensional (3-D) video were created and disseminated.  The extensive sets of created video traces are publicly available free of charge through the video trace library at http://trace.eas.asu.edu. Detailed usage guidelines and tutorials on the use of the video traces in communications and networking research have been published and are also available from the video trace library web site.

The created video traces have been statistically analyzed so as to inform the development of video streaming protocols for communication networks as well as the specific usage of the video traces in network simulations. Generally, the H.264 and H.265/HEVC video streams have significantly higher bit rate variability than previous MPEG encoded video streams, making video smoothing and buffering crucial for efficient video networking. Key insights from the statistical analyses of H.264 single-layer (non-scalable) and scalable video encodings are that (i) differentiated prioritization of the different hierarchical B frame levels in single-layer H.264 SVC has a relatively small effect compared to multiplexer buffering on statistical multiplexing; (ii) H.264 SVC Coarse Grain Scalability (CGS) has relatively high encoding overheads for limited video bit rate adaptability, and (iii) H.264 SVC Medium Grain Scalability (MGS) provides high video bit rate adaptability for very low encoding overheads. The efficiency of H.264 SVC MGS was found to depend to a high degree on the stream extracting mechanism. A simple temporal layer based extraction mechanism was found to perform almost as well as a compute-intensive optimized extraction approach. The analysis also found the H.264 MGS streams have significantly higher traffic variability than corresponding single-layer streams at the frame time scale. However, at the time scale of Groups of Pictures (GoPs), MGS streams have significantly lower traffic variability than their single-layer counterparts. Also, throughout, MGS streams extracted over the time horizon of the complete stream have significantly higher traffic variability than streams extracted over the time horizon of individual GoPs.

For 3-D video, the analysis found that multi-view (MV) representation and coding specifically developed for 3-D video is more rate-distortion (RD) efficient, i.e., gives lower average traffic bit rate for a given video quality, than frame sequential (FS) representation formats that employ conventional two-dimensional single-layer video encoding; both of these approaches are more RD efficient than the side-by-side (SBS) representation that has been experimented with in some distribution networks. However, the traffic variability of MV representation and coding is significantly higher than for the FS and SBS formats. When statistically multiplexing a small number of unsmoothed streams, the FS representation therefore requires smaller network bandwidth than the MV representation. Only through smoothing the MV traffic or statistically multiplexing a large number of streams can the RD efficiency gains of the MV representation and coding be reaped during network transport.
